title: Reticent Definition & Meaning | Dictionary.com
description: Reticent definition, disposed to be silent or not to speak freely; reserved. See more.
cleaned_text: reticent [See synonyms for reticent on Thesaurus.com](https://www.thesaurus.com/browse/reticent) disposed to be silent or not to speak freely; [reserved](/browse/reserved). reluctant or restrained. Compare Meanings Click for a side-by-side comparison of meanings. Use the word comparison feature to learn the differences between similar and commonly confused words. Origin of reticent1 Other words for reticent Opposites for reticent Other words from reticent - ret·i·cence, ret·i·cen·cy, noun - ret·i·cent·ly, adverb - - un·ret·i·cent, adjective - un·ret·i·cent·ly, adverb Words that may be confused with reticent [reluctant](/browse/reluctant), reticent Words Nearby reticent Dictionary.com Unabridged Based on the Random House Unabridged Dictionary, © Random House, Inc. 2023 How to use reticent in a sentence The fewer women who take companies public, the more reticent the check writers are, because they may have never seen somebody like you. [Bumble gave women more power in dating. Now the app is giving women power in the boardroom.](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/02/05/dating-app-bumble-ipo-/)| Jena McGregor | February 5, 2021 [| Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/02/05/dating-app-bumble-ipo-/) New hires are more hesitant to say they don't understand their responsibilities or reticent to ask how to do certain tasks via Zoom versus in person. [Do your neighbors want to get vaccinated?](https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/01/16/1016264/covid-vaccine-acceptance-us-county/)| Karen Hao | January 16, 2021 [| MIT Technology Review](https://www.technologyreview.com/2021/01/16/1016264/covid-vaccine-acceptance-us-county/) Unfortunately, they have also been far too reticent on the need for better access to medicine. [Big Pharma's new CEOs must step up to erase inequities in drug access](https://fortune.com/2020/12/15/big-pharma-ceos-medicine-drug-a/)| matthewheimer | December 15, 2020 [| Fortune](https://fortune.com/2020/12/15/big-pharma-ceos-medicine-drug-a/) In contrast to generally more reticent American producers, who rarely go on the record on this subject, Lloyd Webber seems willing to talk about his efforts for as long as there is battery life in a recording device. [Mike Leigh Is the Master Filmmaker Who Hates Hollywood](http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/14/mike-leigh-is-the-master-filmmaker-who-hates-hollywood.html?source=dictionary)| Nico Hines | October 14, 2014 [| THE DAILY BEAST](http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/14/mike-leigh-is-the-master-filmmaker-who-hates-hollywood.html?source=dictionary) When it comes to his own role in the story, Tomlinson is surprisingly reticent. ['Fives and Twenty-Fives' Is Fiction Honed in a Combat Zone](http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/08/25/fives-and-twenty-fives-is-fiction-honed-in-a-combat-zone.html?source=dictionary)| Brian Castner | August 25, 2014 [| THE DAILY BEAST](http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/08/25/fives-and-twenty-fives-is-fiction-honed-in-a-combat-zone.html?source=dictionary) President James Madison, at the time closely allied with Thomas Jefferson, was not reticent about discussing wealth inequality. [The Floating Light of the Goodwin Sands](http://www.gutenberg.org/files/21735/21735-h/21735-h.htm)| R.M. Ballantyne Indeed, earlier that morning he had been closely questioned by the commandant, but had been equally reticent. [The Doctor of Pimlico](http://www.gutenberg.org/files/22654/22654-h/22654-h.htm)| William Le Queux Laura was inclined to be reticent, but Tanqueray drew her out by congratulating her on her popularity, on the way she kept it up. [The Creators](http://www.gutenberg.org/files/25971/25971-h/25971-h.htm)| May Sinclair Some of the foot pedestrians are said to have been less reticent about the lamp-posts. But we all know that this is a subject on which scientific men are apt to be reticent.
